block.p: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., Zurich, the engineering concern, and Ansaldo S.p.A., an Italian state-owned engineering company, ended their joint venture accords. * Calvary Holdings Inc., New York, which owns about 2 percent of the common shares of Diceon Electronics Inc., Irvine, Calif., started a tender offer for the shares it does not already own at $5.25 a share. * Crane Co., New York, a diversified building concern, sold two of its operating units, Sea-Pac Sales and McAvity, for a total of about $19 million. * Divi Hotels N.V., Ithaca, N.Y., said that Tomdor Ltd. had agreed to purchase the Divi Anchorage Beach Hotel on Antigua for $12 million. * Gradco Systems Inc., Irvine, Calif., a maker of copier sorters, said it had agreed to sell substantially all of the assets of its copier business to its majority-owned subsidiary Gradco (Japan) Inc. * Interco Inc., St. Louis, ended its agreement to sell Sky City Stores Inc. to Sky City Holding Corp., an investor group. No reason was given. * Morgan Keegan Inc., Memphis, said that it had completed the acquisition of substantially all operating assets of Scharff & Jones Inc., an investment firm based in New Orleans. Terms were not disclosed. * Pet Inc., St. Louis, a food products subsidiary of the Whitman Company, said it would close its frozen pie plant in Frankfort, Mich., on Feb. 3. The factory's 115 workers will be offered severance packages. * Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, Jerusalem, said it had entered into a memorandum of intent with W. R. Grace & Co., New York, the diversified industrial concern, for Teva to purchase Grace's 49.8 percent interest in Tag Pharmaceuticals Inc. for $20 million. * Toyota Motor Corp., Tokyo, said it will begin an experimental four-day workweek at its Japanese auto factories in January. * Woolworth Corp., New York, said that it had opened its first store in what had been East Germany. The site in Halle was occupied by Woolworth's German subsidiary before World War II.
